lines.text: Now and then, for no good reason, life will haul off and knock a man flat.
Why did you shoot Rosemary?
She was sick.
Well, you were sick. How come we didn't shoot you?
That was different.
[Old Yeller has contracted hydrophobia and must be put down; Katie brings out the gun]
No, Mama!
There's no hope for him now, Travis. He's suffering. You know we've got to do it.
Yes, Mama. But he was my dog. I'll do it.
If that don't beat all. I never saw such a dog.
And you won't never see another one like him.
What's Papa gonna sell our steers for?
For money, of course.
What's money?
That's what you buy things with.
What do you mean by buy things?
Well when you have money, you give it to people for stuff. They say you can get anything for money.
Anything? What's it look like?
I never seen but one piece. A dollar bill Papa had.
What'd Papa buy with his dollar?
Nothing, it wasn't no good.
But you just said you could get anything with money.
Well, you can, but Papa's was Confederate.
What's Confederate money?
Confederate money? Well, it's...
Well?
Don't you ever run out of questions?
[Travis has asked how he can tell if a creature has hydrophobia]

You can't hardly tell at first, not till they get to the point of slobbering and staggering around. When you see a critter in that fix, you know for sure. But you want to watch for others that ain't that far along. Now, you take a bobcat or a fox. You know they'll run if you give 'em the chance. But when one don't run, or maybe makes fight at you, why, you shoot him and shoot him quick. After he's bitten you, it's too late.
Now Arliss, you ride back here with Yeller.
On a count of he's a sicker Injun than me?
Yes.
Papa, you ain't forgetting the horse.
What horse?
Now Papa, you know I've been aching all over for a good horse to ride. I've told you time and again.
What you're needing more than a horse is a good dog.
Yes sir, but what I'm wanting most is a horse.
Alright, you act a man's part and I'll bring you a man's horse.
You crazy, wonderful dog!
Travis? If you could just come to like the pup. He's - he's *part* Old Yeller.
Maybe *part* Old Yeller, but he ain't Old Yeller.
